docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- Chlorine in drinking water can increase the risk of cancer. THE FACTS -- Companies that sell water filters often claim that the chlorine in most tap water causes cancer. Is it true? Scientists say chlorination can produce at least one group of chemical byproducts, trihalomethanes, that are considered carcinogenic. But studies over the years have differed on whether levels of these compounds in tap water adversely affect health.
docs.abstract: There is some evidence that byproducts of chlorination are linked to increase risk of cancer, but findings are disputed by other studies; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers have found that smokers may be at higher risk for becoming infected with the virus that causes AIDS. The study, which appears in the journal Sexually Transmitted Infections, says it is not clear why smokers would be more likely to become infected with the virus, H.I.V., than nonsmokers.

headline.main: Smoking Tied to Increased Risk of H.I.V.

docs.abstract: British researcher Dr Andrew Furber conducts study that finds those people who smoke are at increased risk of becoming infected with HIV virus; other research already suggests that smoking may increase risk of getting many types of infections; Furber study is published in journal Sexually Transmitted Infections; drawing (M)
